items.a: It’s a setup where LEDs behind/around your monitor change color based on what’s on-screen, creating an ambient glow that matches the content.

items.q: ARGB vs RGB — what’s the difference?
items.a: RGB is usually 12V 4-pin (12V+R+G+B), so the whole strip changes color together. ARGB is usually 5V 3-pin (5V+Data+GND), so each LED can be controlled individually. RGB is best for uniform static color, while ARGB supports flowing and per-LED effects.

items.q: Can I plug RGB and ARGB into each other?
items.a: No. Plugging 5V ARGB into a 12V RGB header can burn LEDs immediately; plugging 12V RGB into 5V ARGB usually will not work and can still damage hardware. Always verify pin count (3-pin vs 4-pin) and header labels before connecting.

items.q: Why is my device not detected?
items.a: Most common causes: cable/port issues (charge-only cable, flaky hub), driver/service conflicts from vendor RGB suites, or sleep/wake power settings. Start with Compatibility → Not detected.
Lower latency generally feels more “locked” to the screen, but stability matters more. A slightly higher-latency setup that never drops devices is often the better experience.
